III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section
Description (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health
service policies and procedures addressing all of the
following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and
behavioral health care.
(e) Dispensing medication.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth was placed at Vista Maria from 05/17/2022 to 08/04/2023.
There are concerns for medical neglect and failure to provide
youth’s medication for type I diabetes mellitus, resulting in risk of
medical emergency of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). Youth’s
diabetes care was previously at Mott and was transferred to
Children's Hospital of Michigan in June 2022 when youth moved
to Vista Maria. Youth’s A1C was 9.6 at the time of last visit with
Mott in 5/2022. Youth returned to Mott on 8/26/23 with an A1C
greater than 14%, which shows an average blood glucose of
greater than 355 for the past 3 months (maybe longer) while
residing at Vista Maria. The caregivers report they were given
expired and incomplete diabetes supplies and medications when
they took over youth’s care. Additionally, youth did not have any
help or supervision with diabetes care.
Investigation This complaint was received on 09/06/2023 and assigned for joint
investigation with MDHHS Specialist.
I interviewed Complainant/Hospital Social Worker via telephone on
09/07/2023. She reported Youth A was previously a patient at U of M
but was transferred to Children’s Hospital last year. Youth A has now
been transferred back to U of M since her change in placement. She
reported there are concerns in reference to Youth A's A1C being 14
when it should be at 7.
I spoke with MDHHS Specialist 1 via telephone on 09/07/2023. She
reported MDHHS Specialist 2 completed a well-being verification on
Youth A at her current foster home placement by MDHHS Specialist
on 09/06/2023.
I interviewed Youth A’s Foster Care Worker (FCW) on 09/13/2023 via
telephone. FCW reported Youth A was placed at Vista Maria for
approximately 1 year and on 08/04/2023 she was moved to a relative
placement. On 08/04/2023 FCW transported Youth A to her relative
2

placement, at which time Youth A was provided with 30-days of
medical supplies and medication. All the medications were current
and there were no missing or expired medication or supplies. On
08/30/2023 Youth A was moved to a licensed foster care home. FCW
said it was while Youth A was at the relative placement her diabetes
was not being managed correctly. FCW said while Youth A was at
Vista Maria, the facility was following up with the diabetic clinic at
Children’s Hospital and there were never any concerns regarding the
facility not providing Youth A with supervision in managing, testing
her glucose, or taking her prescribed medication. Youth A was never
hospitalized while placed at Vista Maria.
I interviewed Youth A via telephone on 09/13/2023. Youth A has
been at her current placement for two weeks. She was previously
placed at Vista Maria and while at Vista Maria she was testing her
blood sugar and taking her insulin medication daily. The nurse and
supervisor monitored her when she tested and took her medication.
Youth A reported she was seen by a doctor at Children’s Hospital,
and they did change her dosage because her sugar level was
running high. She denied missing or not taking her medication while
at Vista Maria. Youth A said her sugar levels have been lower since
being at her current placement.
I interviewed Nurse at the facility on 09/15/2023, in collaboration with
MDHHS Specialist 1. Nurse has been employed at the facility for five
years and is the Health Service Manager. She reported Youth A was
placed at the facility for one year and at the time of placement she
was trained by U of M team in reference to Youth A’s diabetic care.
She was trained on medication management, testing blood sugar,
carb count, checking for ketones, and what to do if glucose level is
too high or too low. She then trained the staff who administrate and
monitored Youth A testing and medication. Youth A’s A1C, and
glucose level did run high while at the facility, but Youth A was
compliant with testing and taking her medication. Youth A’s glucose
was tested four times a day and was being reported to the diabetic
clinic at Children’s Hospital by email weekly. The diabetic team
determined the insulin level and emailed the nurse. Youth A would
test her glucose level while being supervised by Nurse or the
supervisor, and based on the glucose level and her carb count they
used the chart to determine the dial on her insulin pen. Youth A was
not on a restricted diet, but Youth A was being monitored and
encouraged to eat healthy foods and smaller portions. Nurse said
when Youth A was discharged from Vista Maria, the relatives were
provided with medication, insulin pens, Humalog, Lantus, needles for
pens, emergency items for low blood sugar, Dexcom information,
and the contact number for the medical supply company.
3

I interviewed Staff 1 at the facility on 09/15/2023, in collaboration with
MDHHS Specialist 1. Staff 1 is a team leader and has been
employed at the facility for three years. Staff 1 works first shift and
was trained on Youth A’s glucose testing and medication dispensing.
She reported Youth A was compliant with testing and taking her
medication. She said based on her glucose level and carb intake,
they used a carb count chart to determine how much insulin Youth A
needed to take, and if her glucose was too high, they would check
her ketones and contact the nurse. Youth A tested her sugar four
times, and the readings were entered in the computer and monitored
by the nurse. She said Youth A’s sugar levels were high and thinks
that Youth A was sneaking food from the school and not reporting
everything that she eats.
I interviewed Therapist at the facility on 09/15/2023, in collaboration
with MDHHS Specialist 1. Therapist was also trained by U of M
diabetic clinic in reference to Youth A diabetes care at the time of
placement. She reported that while Youth A was at the facility Youth
A did express frustration for having certain food portioned for her due
to her diabetes. Youth A was complaint with testing and taking her
insulin medication. Youth A’s sugar level did run high and there was
constant communication with the diabetic clinic at Children’s
Hospital. She said Youth A was never hospitalized or required
emergency care due to her sugar being too high.
On 10/18/2023 a MIC predisposition conference held with MDHHS
Specialist, Supervisor, and Foster Care Worker. There is no
Findings.
Documents Reviewed:
• Medical records from Childrens Hospital. Youth A was seen
quarterly by Pediatric Endocrinology at Children’s Hospital.
➢ On 6/30/2022. Youth A is diagnosed with
uncontrolled type 1 diabetes mellitus with
hyperglycemia. Youth A is to start using continuous
glucose monitor due to recurrent hypoglycemia and
hypoglycemia unawareness. A1c is 10. Insulin
doses prescribed: Lantus 17 units at 8pm,
Humalog/NovoLog- insulin to carb ratio 1:12 at
meals, correction factor 45.
➢ On 10/03/2022 Youth A’s A1c is 11.6, she has been
testing 4 times a day, denies missed doses of
insulin, admits to limited activity at Vista Maria, and
reports she is being supervised by the nurse at
Vista Maria.
➢ On 01/12/2023 Youth A’s A1C is 12.4. Youth A
glucometer was reviewed, and it was verified she
has been checking glucose monitor 4x per day.
4

Prescriptions updated: Lantus 37 units daily, insulin
to carb ratio 1:5 at meals, correction factor 20.
Diabetes plan: approve for pump, approved for
continuous glucose monitoring.
➢ On 4/20/2023 Youth A has been consistently
wearing her Dexcom glucose monitor. A1C is 13.5.
In March 2023 Children’s Hospital was contacted
due to persistent hyperglycemia and therefore
Youth A’s Lantus dose was increased from 40 to 50
units. Insulin doses: Lantus 35 units BID, Insulin to
carb ratio 1:4 at meals, correction factor 15.
➢ 08/24/2023 Youth A was transferred to U of M Motts
pediatric diabetes clinic. It was reported that Youth
A has not been wearing her CGM because of issues
with the transmitter. She has been doing finger
pokes. Her blood sugar has been high. A1C is >14.
Her current doses were reported as Lantus 7,
insulin to carb ratio 1:4, correction 15. U of M
changed doses to Lantus 13 units once daily, insulin
to carb ratio 1:12 all meals and snacks, correction
1:90, target 150. U of M discussed testing blood
sugar 5 times per day, ensuring the insulin regimen
is followed, and training caregivers.
• Youth A’s DHHS-5921 Health Information for Residential
Discharge dated 08/04/2023. The following medications
were provided to caregiver at the time of discharge:
➢ Aripiprazole 2MG
➢ Bupropion HCL XL 300
➢ Mirtazapine 30 MG
➢ Prasosin 2MG
➢ True Metrix glucose strips for checking blood
glucose.
➢ True Metrix BG Meter for blood glucose check
➢ Sure, comfort Safety Lancets
➢ Novofine Autocover 30G for injection
➢ Ketone Strips for urine ketones
➢ Vitamin D3 2000U tablet
➢ Caltrate 600 MG/800MG Tab
➢ Benzoyl Peroxide 5% wash for acne
➢ Clindamycin Phos 1% pledge for acne
➢ Lantus Solostar 100 unit
➢ Humalog 100U/ML Kwikpen
➢ Baqsimi 3MG spray- inhale 3MG during seizure
➢ Humalog 100U/ML Kwikpen
➢ Glucagon 1MG Emergency Kit for hypoglycemia
5

Analysis The facility is not in violation as there is insufficient evidence
based on medical records, documentation provided by the facility,
interviews with Staff, Nurse, and Youth A, showed facility was
following the recommended medical care/medication as
prescribed by the diabetic clinic at Children’s Hospital.
Documentation provided showed Youth A was provided with
sufficient medical supplies and medication at the time of discharge
from the facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
